article.headline: Dominoâs Pizza could snap up market share with âimprovedâ chicken wings
article.body: Dominoâs Pizza Inc. has introduced a chicken wing menu option that BTIG analysts think could lure diners away from Wingstop Inc. The 10-piece wing item has new sauces and a price tag, $7.99, that analysts say will be enticing to value-conscious customers. Dominoâs DPZ, -2.50% Â previously had wings on the menu, but, according to Richard Allison, the companyâs chief executive who spoke about the new item on the Thursday earnings call, they were in need of improvement. âIn our view, the upgraded product quality coupled with the investment behind advertising to support the rollout could allow the brand to take share in this multibillion-dollar category,â wrote BTIG analysts led by Peter Saleh. Read:Red Robin Gourmet Burgers cut 55 menu items due to coronavirus and doesnât plan to bring them back âFurthermore, we note that the aggressive price point of 79 cents per wing compared with Wingstop which is typically north of $1 per wing could result in some pricing pressure across the category.â BTIG recently downgraded to neutral from buy at Wingstop WING, +0.70% Â on concerns that the company lacked the funds for expansion. BTIG rates Dominoâs stock buy with a $440 price target. Dominoâs is upping its game in the chicken wing category in time to meet heightened demand. âWhile the announced menu innovation isnât necessarily new, we would point to the strong performance of the chicken category both pre-COVID and since, and believe there may ultimately be greater opportunity for trial and check add-on from an improved wing product vs. other ânewâ items,â said RBC Capital Markets in a note. See:Skyrocketing COVID-19 cases around the U.S. slows dine-in restaurant recovery RBC rates Dominoâs stock outperform with a price target of $458, up from $435. Dominoâs reported earnings and revenue that blew past expectations, with U.S. same-store sales soaring 16.1%. Dominoâs stock closed Friday down 4.3%. Shares have rallied 32.8% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87% Â has slipped 0.2% for the period. Analysts have been upbeat about Dominoâs and its pizza delivery competitor Papa Johnâs International Inc. during the pandemic due to their digital ordering, delivery and contactless capabilities. âFrom here, value will be a major focus, while menu innovation could help maintain outperformance,â wrote UBS in a note. UBS rates Dominoâs stock neutral with a price target of $415, up from $385. Donât miss:Online food prices jump as food companies struggle to meet demand Stifel analysts think Dominoâs can maintain its same-store sales momentum. Dominoâs said it would be launching additional items in the coming months. âWe believe many investors will find the wing offering a bit underwhelming, but additional launches in the coming one to two months would represent the most product launches Dominoâs has ever had in a single year,â wrote analysts led by Chris OâCull. âWe are confident management will leverage the various launches to create new menu messaging and awareness, calling attention to Dominoâs evergreen value platform.â Stifel rates Dominoâs stock hold and raised its price target to $400 from $360.
